### Enhanced Information (For Contextual Support):
The drug of choice for bleeding oesophageal varices is Octreotide. Octreotide works by causing vasoconstriction of the splanchnic circulation, which reduces portal pressure and helps control bleeding from oesophageal varices. This aligns with the consensus that Octreotide is effective in acute management of variceal bleeding due to its ability to decrease portal hypertension. Propranolol, while useful in preventing variceal bleeding by reducing portal hypertension, is not typically used for acute bleeding control. Ethanolamine oleate is used in sclerotherapy to obliterate varices, but it is not the first-line pharmacological treatment. Phytonadione (Vitamin K) improves coagulation but is not directly effective in controlling variceal bleeding. The evidence paths confirm Octreotide's role in treating conditions related to blood circulation, supporting its use in this context.
